Proposed patch is as follows. Note that I avoid the easy way of checking for overflow ie.

beg_i + len < beg_i

since that implies a signed integer overflow which is officially undefined behavior in C and reportedly may lead to unexpected results on some architectures. But feel free to implement a patch however you want.

diff --git a/ext/strscan/strscan.c b/ext/strscan/strscan.c
index 9b52fea..7dfe17a 100644
--- a/ext/strscan/strscan.c
+++ b/ext/strscan/strscan.c
@@ -153,7 +153,7 @@ static VALUE
 extract_beg_len(struct strscanner *p, long beg_i, long len)
 {
     if (beg_i > S_LEN(p)) return Qnil;
-    if (beg_i + len > S_LEN(p))
+    if (len < 0 || beg_i > (LONG_MAX - len) || beg_i + len > S_LEN(p))
         len = S_LEN(p) - beg_i;
     return infect(str_new(p, S_PBEG(p) + beg_i, len), p);
 }

Note that malice isn't necessarily required to trigger this vulnerability; any Ruby program that uses strscan to simply operate on large buffers may unknowingly exfiltrate secret data (if the peek()'d data ever leaves the system).

The vulnerability is not expected to work on 64 bit systems because of the much larger limits of the long type, and the requirement that the sizes of the buffers and available heap memory are accordingly large.

Tested on ruby-2.3.1

activities.markdown_message:
Confirmed.
I think the condition can be:

    if (len > S_LEN(p) - beg_i)
        len = S_LEN(p) - beg_i;

str_new0 will catch negative values so you are right.

This might also be vulnerable:

 719 static VALUE
 720 strscan_getch(VALUE self)
 721 {
 722     struct strscanner *p;
 723     long len;
 724 
 725     GET_SCANNER(self, p);
 726     CLEAR_MATCH_STATUS(p);
 727     if (EOS_P(p))
 728         return Qnil;
 729 
 730     len = rb_enc_mbclen(CURPTR(p), S_PEND(p), rb_enc_get(p->str));
 731     if (p->curr + len > S_LEN(p)) {                                                                                                                      
 732         len = S_LEN(p) - p->curr; 
 733     }
 734     p->prev = p->curr;
 735     p->curr += len;
 736     MATCHED(p);
 737     adjust_registers_to_matched(p);
 738     return extract_range(p, p->prev + p->regs.beg[0],
 739                             p->prev + p->regs.end[0]);
 740 }

I cannot verify it at this very moment. But if it is vulnerable, the bug in this in function has the additional consequence that it will set p->curr to an OOB position, which may have further ramifications via functions that rely on a correct `curr value.

Will report back on this later.

activities.message:
I believe ```getch``` isn't vulnerable since the underlying ```rb_enc_mbclen``` automatically caps the length that it returns to ```end - start```, so even multi-byte encodings like UTF32 won't cause an overflow.

Can you give an estimated time/date of bug resolution and disclosure?

Thanks.
